review_title: Ingenix possesses all of the advantages and disadvantages of a large company
job_title: QA Analyst in Rocky Hill, CT
pros: There is a commitment to work/life balance, decent salary, and decent PTO.  Employees are empowered.
cons: Littl;e to no communication at times with various business teams.  Too many assumptions of roles of other technical groups.

pros: Telecommuting positions are available in some areas, starting pay is not bad, first year paid time off is fairly good
cons: Raises are practically non existent and are solely at supervisors' discretion; if you're well liked you'll get a bigger raise, if you're not currently in favor you'll get little or no raise at all. In 2009 there were no raises for anyone even though the company made billions more in profits than forecast. There's no increase in paid time off for 5 years and our insurance benefits are horrible. For 2011 our health insurance is 80/20; much like Medicare and with huge deductibles. Local management is horrible; totally unqualified and untrained. At my location the management style is threats, intimidation and retaliation but because the department makes so much money thanks to Federal subsidies, corporate doesn't care. We are treated and talked to as if we're children. We are rarely given the tools we need to do our jobs; we have computer programs that seldom work, information that is 3 or 4 years out of date and managers actually get angry if they're questioned about such things. Our job performances are rated based on "quality" evaluations where a recorded call is dissected line by line and points deducted if we don't follow scripts written by people who've never worked with the customers or answered a call. It may take 3 hours for a "quality analyst" to score a 3 minute phone call and much of the scoring is completely subjective. Every time a different "quality analyst" scores your calls you have to adjust yourself to that particular person. They do not take into account whether or not the customer was pleased or satisfied with the results of the call; if you did not say the 857 things they want you to get in on each call, you lose points on that call. The company is so incredibly cheap that we had a company picnic for the first time this year but had to pay if we wanted to attend. Needless to say, very few employees attended. For customer service week this year employees who won drawings received as prizes coupons for slurpees. Yes, slurpees. From a company whose CEO makes millions per year.

review_title: Very unprofessional, poor pay, and no job security no matter how much you excel.
job_title: Licensed Health Agent in Orlando, FL
pros: This is the only company that I have ever worked for that I cannot think of one pro to say about the company.  Well maybe a pro is that if you need a job really bad they will take anyone with a pulse.
cons: As long as you work there you will never get a raise even if you help out in many other areas and do a great job.  They use the excuse that they don't give raises because they have their "pay for performance" but it is a joke for many reasons.  First, the pfp varies widely from account to account as well as the requirements to get it.  Second, the company is constantly getting and losing accounts (I have been on 7 different ones) and you are in training and nesting so much you are only eligible for pfp half the year at best.  And third, since they call it pfp and not commission they can and do chose not to pay it at times due to very lame excuses and you can't legally have any recourse.  Favoritism is rampant.  I've repeatedly witnessed employees with great attitudes, great sales stats and metrics lose out in being chosen for positions in favor of lazy workers who surf the internet all day- and I mean over and over.  There is a general atmosphere at the company that everyone is disposable.

review_title: Big Corp acts with huge impunity...aggressive strategy to get bigger=ignores regulations/mistreats employees
pros: Big corporation should provide big opportunity but that is not the case when the top leadership sets the agenda to enrich themselves at the literal expense of the corporation's long term health--and integrity of corporate policies and employees.  UHG is aggressively acquiring yet does not care to properly onboard the acquisitions or correct their completely out of compliance processes. UHG is only interested in growing their market cap through such reckless acquisition.  They are now listed on largest market cap list on stock exchange which makes them an almost certain holding for many retirement funds, thus boosting UHG's stock price artificially and with no regard for proper fundamentals of the corporation, itself. UHG pays slightly higher because you will need it to pay extra out of pocket for their terrible benefits.  They are shifty from the start!
cons: Every year on the annual survey, 99% of the employees rate the health insurance choices provided by United Healthgroup health insurance company as the most unsatisfactory of all!  such a fact bespeaks volumes as to what regard or value that UHG actually holds any employee.  Potential employees beware!  If you don't do your due diligence on this company, you will get the short end.  It is like anything else, "do your homework first, before making a commitment or placing your livelihood dependent upon such a proven lackluster employer!

review_title: Worst Company I've Ever Worked For
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: There is not one pro I can think of
cons: Work load is inhumane.  Employee turnover is tremendous.  Managers have no spine and don't support their direct reports because they are so afraid to lose their jobs.  Lots of lay offs, which are a smoke screen for being fired.  No appreciation no matter how hard you work, no matter how much money you make for the company, no matter how many hours you work.  Work is expected 7 days a week, up to 16 hours a day, always.  I still have contact with employees there who begin work at 6 a.m. and work until after 7 p.m.  The overall annual raise is 3% for everyone with the exception of being allowed to give one employee on your team 5%. Reviews are always meet expectations unless you qualify for the 5%, then you'll get exceeds expectations just that one time.  Telecommuters used to be reimbursed for their cells phones and internet connections but that stopped.  Sales folks comp plans were decreased by two-thirds.  They'll fire someone without any plans to hire a replacement and just throw the work at someone else who already has more than they can handle.  With so many layers of management, the favoritism allows some managers to practice unethical behaviors.  If you call HR for assistance, you won't get it, as they always favor management.  When management has you pegged to leave, they will do everything to push you over the edge so you'll leave voluntarily as they don't want to pay the severance.  I have never heard so many employees speak so badly about the working conditions or complain about how unhappy they are.  Compensation is mediocre.  Raises, although given every year, are minimum.  Tuition reimbursement is limited to $1,500 a year.  Medical benefits are the absolute worse only providing catastrophic coverage.  Deductibles are high $1500+ and out of pocket is around $4,000 before they'll cover 80% and this is a health care company.  The work employees like dogs and boast about their earnings to the stockholders at the expense of employees.  It's a very sick environment.

review_title: Good job, at a rapidly changing organization
pros: Good benefits, good industries (healthcare:  services, IT), and successful company.
cons: The company is going through many changes (including acquiring and integrating smaller health / IT companies).    Its great that the company is making major moves in such a crucial period of health care innovation, but work life is a little inefficient due to this.

pros:
Work Life balance 
But it is bad also. There is just too much of work life balance i.e. At max 40% meaningful engagement at any point of time. Work life balance is towards unhealthy side.
Lip work as appreciation for technical good work.
cons:
Having worked with some Captive organizations now, i feel UHG india is the worst by significant margin being run by some really clueless senior middle management. 
In my tenure i have seen someone getting promoted in a year time for completely mis managing a big team and dwindling it down to 30% of its initial capacity. Later on the same leader trying to add employees without any projects in pipeline. I feel for those new employees where they are getting into the mess.

You can not ( i mean can not ) take what they say about the work in interviews on face value. In some cases the work itself is not there. They are just trying to fill empty position ID's created by employee resignations. There will be months without any work. A well reasoned self respecting IT guy will go mad without work here.
I have seen people coming to office just to Turn on the Computer ( Some level 27 guys as well ) or running their own business using UHG as a side income. Politics is just a class above anywhere else and is at a very unhealthy level.

Too much party without any real success to spice up the "no work" boring life. Come on - every dollar UHG saves is a dollar for a patient care. They do not value what they say.

No Technology thought leadership. When whole world is becoming engineering heavy - This organization is becoming more managerial heavy. Its well known that Captive organizations offer less head room for promotion where as you get to own the work you do. The pride of doing something technically good for your organization should be there. Here its futile to even try to start anything. You will be shot down by over conservative less techie management. Or they will provide lip service to create it as if they are providing lollipop to a crying baby.

There are some good people also and good work happening in pockets But they are few in number and rapidly depleting. The soul of the organization is lost in India. The way it was created by Mr Mishra is no longer now present. Its running for the sake of running. If i were in UHG IT management in MPLS, i would give a critical look at the india leadership in IT. UHG india is a money sink created and it will continue to bleed sick patient insurance dollars without any bang for its true worth.

The sad part is there are too many managers playing the system. You will be forced to join this ghetto and take wrong advantage of the system or you will be sidelined/ ignored from a broad sector of management. You will be talked about in parties as a non compliant member. 

Management communicates with well articulated english statements. You won't find any value or meaning from what they say. The sentences are well formulated at an abstraction level where you can relate it to World peace forum talks. 

BTW i still think business process outsourcing running out of india is a value add to UHG and its doing good. on a conservative scale even If 60% IT from india is abolished UHG will not be impacted.

I so regret getting into this company and wasting my productive IT career while i was there. I was not a low end performer as some would think from this review. In all organizations i have worked i have got awards from near CIO level for my hands on technical work and in UHG also i have been rewarded from same level. However I sincerely feel its not an engineering / IT organization. If you are a IT professional and value your IT career do not join this company. If you want to take a break from IT, It can be a good max 1 year parking space.

5. All directors are each other friends or have have work in the past which disallows the diversification.

Advice: Never work in Quality Engineering because there is no respect for your work, you are being regularly abused by Development Managers, Development Managers have no idea about QE and they make bad statements on floor, Lack of Automation cause everything is being run by US and you can only execute.
8. Not a employee friendly organization (Works in PE so can talk about PE)
9. Lot of politics played by each Director and you could be meshed in them.

job_title: Licensed Insurance Sales Agent in Centennial, CO
pros: If you are desperate for a paycheck then accept this position, they will hire anyone.  Be aware that the person sitting next to you might have a felony conviction etc.  As long as they are able to pass the health licensing for the state of Colorado Connextions will hire them.  Employees are only a disposable commodity.
cons: I had initially been offered one position with a certain salary and I resigned my contract position assuming that what I was offered in writing was accurate.  When I showed up as agreed upon the position didn't exist and no one ever bothered to inform me.  I really needed an income so they offered me an agent role at a much lower salary--an hourly wage and the pay for performance was made to seem as if one worked hard one could earn about 40K per year.  The PFP was a total lie.  I had been ranked as the top agent in April of 2014 over 200 agents in two locations.  My PFP was less than 10% of what I'd been told.  When I inquired as to the discrepancy, I was told "things change" "the client" Kaiser changed their minds as to the payout.  These were unacceptable comments.  In the 15 months I worked at this horrible place there were 5 different recruiters in the HR department.  Some of whom were contractors so the company could distance themselves from the lies being told to candidates.  Having worked for reputable companies previously and since then I can advise you to keep looking so you don't have to explain the hole in your resume.  You don't want this horrible call center on your resume if you expect to have any professional growth in the insurance industry.  The "coaches" are bullies and if you are pre-disposed to flirting to get ahead then this could be the correct place to work.  I've never worked anywhere where it was acceptable to treat employees as Connextions treats you.  They supposedly have a "dress code" and is enforced only if you aren't part of the clique. There has been a "re-branding" of changing the name to "Optum".  Be aware that the corporate culture has not changed and their values are to NOT value employees.  As an employee this was the worst case of benefits I've ever seen and their core corporate value is to have a revolving door.  They hire agents to work open enrollment and then terminate or make it so horrible that you quit and the process starts again.  There are so many better options, spend the $200 to take a class and get your license independently and do your research to make sure that the carrier has values in line with your own.

pros:
1. There are some very hardworking employees, who deliver good work consistently and put the needs of the clients first and make very good team members.
2. For those with HSAs and on high deductible plans, there are opportunities to meet health targets and earn money towards your HSA.
3. Option to purchase additional PTO but it’s expensive and it’s approved per manager/supervisor discretion.
4. Some opportunity for flexibility in work schedule – helpful to attend kid’s events, go to doctor appointments, etc. and it’s approved per manager/supervisor discretion.
5. Some opportunities for working from home for some departments – saves on gas and commute stress.
6. Volunteering with some organizations that help people in need in the area.
7. Ample parking space
8. Office building is generally quiet.
cons:
1. The pay is low and raises are generally only 2% even for top performers, yet every month employees would get emails saying how well UHG was performing.
2. The health insurance benefits are terrible – high premiums and a spousal penalty is assessed to have your spouse on your plan. Most plans are high deductible and for the low copay plan, prepare to change doctors.
3.  Seasonal work fluctuation - for example, some departments can go months with very little to do, so they're just in the office trying to look busy and getting more and more frustrated because of lack of work, and yet management continue to hire more people into these departments.
4. Opportunities for advancement in this location are bare, many employees are constantly applying for positions in other UHG locations.
5. Turn over is revolving door - most new people after being there a few months realized they had been duped during the interviews and start looking for other jobs.
6. The culture that is reinforced by management is toxic, encourages clicks and employees to spy and tell on each other.
7. The top manager will not allow the supervisors to actually do their work effectively.
8. Manager and supervisors regularly target and harass employees they do not like. For example, pregnant employees not being allowed to work from home when they're not feeling well (if employee does not want to get an occurrence), but the manager/supervisors work from home and have flexible schedules as they please.
9. The vital signs survey results have been very poor over the past few years but there was no change in management and no positive changes on the real issues that employees gave feedback on.
10. Rampant unprofessional behavior among management, they behave like it's their own business and employee feedback to corporate HQ in Minneapolis about this has been ignored (HR will take your feedback but no follow up action is taken).

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Green Bay, WI
pros: Pay. Weekends off. Great co workers.
cons: Literally everything thing else not listed in pros. I read reviews of uhg after I took the job and saw all the bad review and was very worried if I just made the wrong decision. Well I can certainly tell you that yes it was a horrible decision. You will start out in a 16 week training class with about 20 other new hires. If you wonder why so many new hires at a time it's because about half of you won't make it out of training. Turn over is very high!  The building in Green Bay is pretty big. And it's basically empty. No one wants to stay there. Training is good at first but once you start taking calls you will realize you don't know nearly as much as you need to. Trainers will eventually make you feel stupid for asking questions and degrade you in front of others for asking. Multiple people quit my class for the way they were treated. If you manage to last thru training you go into a nesting phase. The supervisors there do absolutely nothing and almost ignore you completely unless you do something wrong. Then you hear from them real quick. They never praise on the good things. Just negative. They want you to be robots. No small talk, no hold time, no emotion. If you don't know an answer to someone's question good luck finding it. You will have to search thru about 1000 documents or "sop's" to find it. Like a needle in a haystack. Don't count on restroom breaks when you have to go. You can only go on your scheduled breaks. If you need to use "personal time" to go then your penalized. Health benefits suck. Very high deductibles and you can't go to the emergency room. Trust these bad reviews. They speak the truth. I wish I had never taken this job.

pros: I met a few nice people at this company who value team success, and foster growth and care about one another and the company.   I  enjoyed some of the relationships that were formed.   Others were not as caring or professional.   They would often have pot lucks and little celebrations with food.
cons:
This is basically a sweatshop.  It is a KPI-driven company that requires even your bathroom breaks be recorded.   Employees are put on a timer as though they are in kindergarten!  Micromanaging the masses is the name of the game, here.  The biggest problem is that the training and the processes are truly over the top and nightmarish.  I could not believe I had become a part of this mess.   Everyone in my class was lost and confused.  Upon talking with a few of them at break time, I learned that they were very upset that they had even come here to begin with... a feeling that had washed over me within just a few days of starting.  The processes were extremely and unnecessarily complex with endless numbers of steps to complete in order to finish just one enrollment, and the instructor could not answer many of our questions.  Each case had its own challenges.  After only two weeks of training,  a new employee is scored on all of their work, and raises are withheld (all .25 cents) if even one mistake is made in the course of a year.   There was an employee who had been there nearly two decades who had never been given a raise.  After being there for a few months, just when I had begun to feel like I was gaining a handle on the process, I was forced to learn a new task.  The training was just as brutal with the second process and again I was among other employees who were confused and upset.  

Each employee is given a cubicle that is about the size of a broom closet and is required to take their laptop home every night - carting it back and forth daily.  There is no longer a cafeteria at this company (just vending machines) and there are only a few microwaves for hundreds of people to use.  Having to stand in line with only a half hour lunch break barely gave me enough time to eat.  The benefits offered to employees are terrible - and this is a health insurance company!!  Employees were often denied a requested day off, and were given the reason that two others had requested the same day off, even though there were 54 people doing the same job.  Additionally, they do not pay out unused earned time off when an employee leaves, since it is not required in NH.  (They seem to always give the employee as little as possible, instead of rewarding them for such hard work. )  The pay is far too low for what a person is expected to endure, here.

pros: There are no PROS working for this horrible company.
cons: Run away! When you start you will enjoy the job only to eventually hate it. This job has no type of structure. They hire any and everybody for management. Managers quit left and right. They are able to change your job title and job duties at the drop of a dime without even consulting you. Also, your hours. No one communicates, it's always business needs at the end of the day. You can do entirely everything they ask within a timely manner and they will still cheat you in your scores at the end of the day. Try being a top 3 performer for a year straight and be told you are receiving less benefits than another employee who has never worked over time and never beat your scores. It's a popularity competition at the end of the day and no one cares about how much work and how much trouble you got them out of at the end of the day. You will be better off working for Uber. This job has taught me a lot. People only look out for themselves at the end of the day. Management doesn't even care about progressing you. Whats the point of a team if you are not striving to make them the best? Management itself is basically only women that talk down on you to get to the top. It's a disgusting environment. I thought Kaiser was bad, this place beats them tops!

review_title: Stressful Job in a Large, Disorganized Company
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Minnetonka, MN
pros: If you negotiate your offer, the pay is acceptable.  Expect a 2% raise, which is pathetic considering how well the company is doing.  My pay was actually less in 2019 because they raised the cost of health care and my raise didn't cover the costs.
cons:
If you've never experienced a dysfunctional organization, then welcome to UnitedHealth Group.  It all begins on your first day.  There is absolutely no orientation for new employees.  You are expected to watch numerous online video clips and figure out everything for yourself.  The IT department is practically non-existent.  There are numbers confusing programs and processes that you have to figure out on your own.  Most of the time even the IT department doesn't have answers.

Onboarding new employees, obtaining hardware and software and technical requests are submitted through an intranet that is so confusing, outdated and useless that it takes weeks to get anything done.  Many requests take multiple approvals, many of which get lost in the system.

If you are working in the Tower expect to work with some of the biggest egos around.  There are too many VPs that have undefined jobs and don't deliver results.  Instead of taking responsibility for their inability, they take out their frustrations on their staff.  Each VP wants to be more important than the other.  So they suck up to the top leaders for time, staff and resources.  

Many employees are overworked, while others, especially certain VPs, are often out of the office on personal junkets.  The dedicated lower level employees carry the department.  Stress levels are high, and rewards are few.  There are no parties, with the exception of Christmas, and no money for team events (even pizza parties are not in the budget).  Gift cards of appreciation are not allowed.  Gestures of recognition are few and far between.


Ironically, the healthcare benefits are the same as you would find at any other company.   Until you reach $2700 a year, you pay out of pocket.  Then the insurance picks up 80%.  

Administrative assistants are used and abused at this company.  Expected to do so much with so few resources, they are overworked and stressed out.  There are so many other companies that have much better working conditions, perks and great atmospheres, that working at UnitedHealthGroup doesn't make sense.

review_title: Stable company with many locations nationwide
job_title: Director of Applications Development in Hartford, CT
pros:
The company is one of the biggest insurance firms in US. It is  avery solid and stable place to work in.
Life work balance
Opportunity to learn healthcare industry
Flexible schedule
cons: Too many levels of management. The company is so big, that sometimes the lack of proper communication between different departments causes inefficiencies. The same work may be duplicated. There is competition between departments.

review_title: If you don't work in a position that supports their core business, you won't feel safe
pros: Possible work at home opportunities
cons:
Having to bite your tongue as you watch leadership bozos think they're making the world a better place.

I was with a company that was bought by United Health Group. They (the people that brought me in to the company) said UHG promised autonomy. Yeah - that lasted a month, maybe. We went through three CEO's in four months.

UHG honestly didn't know what to do with the company once they bought it with an objective to compete with WebMD. Eventually, the entire editorial staff was let go because they began purchasing content from a third party healthcare content provider (which they probably could have done in the first place without purchasing and dismantling an entire company).

We were often not asked to write about certain medical procedures and treatments, mostly out of fear that people they insured would find out about them and then request them, thus effectively lowering company profits.

In my dealings with people from the home office in Minnesota, it was not hard to see that I was not dealing with the best and brightest. It was like walking into a giant pissing contest - collaboration and ideas are frowned upon.

The insurance they offer employees seems worse than what they offer to the general public.

They denied raises based on a "projection" of market conditions, despite the fact that the company had experienced record profits the year before.

If you want to work there because you need a paycheck, that's one thing. But don't get comfortable thinking this is your home and they have your back. That is unless you like being a drone. Don't rock the boat, don't introduce innovations that might make things more efficient and effective.

review_title: The most disappointment I have experienced
pros: The salary was decent. The buddy program is nice.
cons: After my first day of working for Optum, I was asked what I knew about a particular software ( i had no experience with it) and what I knew about the Affordable Care Act (I had no experience working on ACA projects). After being honest about my background, I was told, "Congratulations, you are now on this project. " My first week of being on site, I realized that this was not a good fit for me and I would be doing a dis-service to the client. When I voiced my opinion to my manager, I was told that she understood what I was saying, but I was smart and could figure it out. As time went on, I was asked to take on a PM role (I am not a PM) and had deliverables that were outside my comfort level. After three months, I couldn't take any more and I resigned with two weeks notice. My old manager nor the manager on the project did not bother to reach out to me to see why I was leaving. On Friday at 3:45 pm, I was told that I did not need to come back to the project as my deliverables were met. I informed my current manager and she said that today would be my last day (leaving me shy of a week of pay). She also informed me that per HR, they were not required to pay me my 40 hours of vacation. For a company as large as Optum (a division of United Healthcare), I couldn't believe how unethical they were being. They didn't care about me. I was just a number to them. If they could get away without paying me for my last week and without paying out my PTO bank, then they would save themselves that money. I highly recommend you reconsider before accepting a job offer from them. Also, carefully review their benefit package. The health insurance is awful.

pros: PAID HOLIDAYS, COLLABORATIVE CO-WORKERS. WORK/LIFE BALANCE IS GOOD, MOST ARE NOT FORCED TO WORK OVERTIME.
cons: Optum360 (United Healthcare)  is scrambling to to transition all current Dignity Health applications to Optum360's propriatory software so Dignity Health would have a difficult time in taking back the Revenue Cycle from Optum360 (United Healthcare) . It's well known many in Dignity Health regret the contract with Optum360 after this initial 2 years. It is rumored that someone at Dignity Health must have received quite a payoff to sign over the  Revenue Cycle to Optum360 (Lloyd Dean?) and now Mayo Clinic has signed on with Optum360 / United Healthcare - now the employees of Mayo Clinic will unfortunately experience the hack job Optum360 (United Healthcare) will do to their healthcare benefits, sick pay and PTO.  Dignity Health employees went from the BEST healthcare plan to the worst with Optum360 (United Healthcare)... $2500.00 deductible!  Optum360 (United Healthcare)  likes to call it "shared responsibility" - well isn't that just doublespeak for we expect that you as an employee will have to suffer difficulty financially before we EVER put a dime into your healthcare.  Dignity Health had sick pay, Optum360 does not have any. Do you get sick a couple of times per year, how about your children? Well you can look forward to using your mediocre PTO benefits for these days so in essence, very little "vacation" days for you.    Dignity Health had a pension plan, Optum360 does not.  Are you okay with that? Think many employers no longer offer pension plans?  Maybe so but Dignity Health employees were "sold out" - we didn't ask for Optum360 (United Healthcare)  to take over so we now have lousy healthcare, no sick pay, no pension plan and yet we're asked to "embrace" all of these wonderful changes daily via the barrage of Optum360 emails telling us how wonderful they are.  I was taught "embraces" should feel good not like you're getting abused.  Many in upper Management have bailed - should be a red flag to all.  Optum360 / United Healthcare values NO ONE but their shareholders.  And remember, Optum360 / United Healthcare is a multi-national company, i.e they OUTSOURCE as much work as legally possible.  They cannot legally outsource State Medicaid and Medicare.  I'm sure if they could, they would not have ANY employees in the United States except of course upper management.  Oh, and here is a kicker, they use outside Vendors!  Just think Optum360 (United Healthcare) as a vendor to Dignity Health and Mayo Clinic use outside Vendors!  Yea, Dignity Health (and now Mayo Clinic)  was definitely sold a bill of goods. Too bad it's good employees who suffer the consequences.

review_title: High Risk Telephonic Nurse Case Manager
pros:
-Compensation is on the high end when compared to bedside nursing, but when compared to the amount of daily stress this jobs entails IT'S NOT WORTH IT!!!
-Telecommute
cons:
-Work conditions are horrible. Currently, telephonic nurse queues are ranging 170-240 patients per case manager and these are all HIGH RISK PATIENTS.
-Management does not listen or follow through with employee concerns
-Audits are completed monthly and are very punitive, you get no positive reinforcement, instead you are told what you are not doing or what you could do.
-Considering that this is an INSURANCE COMPANY, the benefits are horrible. Deductible rates are outrageous. 
-Everything is about metrics, patients don't matter to them. Multiple RN's have spoken out about their concerns with high queue volumes and nothing is being done about it.
-You have to get coverage for vacation, which equates to not being able to enjoy it because you cannot find coverage. You come back from vacation and wish you hadn't taken it because you are backlogged with calls.
-No work-life balance at all. You are told during the interview process "40 hours per week". However, once you get in there, you are really pulling 45-50 hour work weeks. This is a salary position so you are not compensated for working overtime. Management doesn't care that you have to work over because they want the goal they give you to get done.  In addition, the stress from this job spills over into your personal life. 
-I hope you like learning independently because once you are out of orientation you pretty much have to learn as you go. There are hundreds of job aides which outline your work process and they are changed all the time. Many time management themselves don't know all the changes that are occurring. 
-Attrition is horrible. People are leaving all the time and new ones coming in. Anyone that tries to refer you to work here, don't do it. They get a referral bonus and don't care what happens to you after you start.

I asked to make up the classess missedr and the manager I spoke with indicated it would be a severe hardship so I offered to resign and was asked to submit resignation letter. However, I rethought things and didn't see why  I should resign when I could not help becoming ill and was willing to do whatever it took to make up class. 

I called again asked again to finish training but found out was terminated. I then asked when the next training class would be and was told by this same person it wouldd be "quite a while". However, not 2 weeks later the role was posted again. This is the part of this entire experience that is most disturbing. I then applied for a similar role in another division of company but they never go back to me and when I checked in was told by a recruiter that the role was postponed--which may or may not be true based on prior misleading statements. I then asked to be reconsidered for the first role and join the upcoming class but they never responded. 

I am truly taken aback by the behavior of this compay. They espouse compassion and integrity but, unfortunatley,  do not practice their values. 

I would advise not to apply or work for this company as  there is a tremendous amount of turnover for this role -- I can see why. They micromanage to the nth degree. I had heard they even go so far as to count the number times you move your mouse over a given time period.  Heaven forbid you get sick because they will kick you to the curb. Yet when I see who they hire instead, those people are usually female, undereducated and have very little time at UHC-this leads me to believe they want someone who they can mold, not someone with original ideas.  This also leads me to believe that they are  dishonest and jealousy in their upper-management team.  Instead of wanting you to succeed they make sure you stay down with the other colored folks.  It is also strife with sexism (at least in my immediate office and locale).  No advancement for males in a highly concentrated area dominated by older female, reverse sexism exists!  I have experienced this throughout my tenure at UHC and am simply sick of it.  I also believe that it's who you know that will get you promoted, I recently applied for a certain position, 2 weeks later was told it was filled, yet came on Glassdoor.com and it is still posted (no it's not a different one HR Talent people it's the same req#- but nice try!).  Upper management brags about yearly profits yet when raises come they say "sorry, we're struggling" then they go and make a big budget movie of themselves (with special 3D effects) dancing around Texas and showing it to employees during Corporate meetings.  I could smell the disgust in the atmosphere from all of the employees who sat near me, yet they all clapped because hey you don't want to upset their boss and CEO.  I'm sure they meant well but it was ill advised and self-serving.  These people need to go to business school and practice ethical and moral modesty.

job_title: Complex Customer Care Representative in Atlanta, GA
pros: Work from home, diverse environment
cons: I had initial video interview first after I applied to job on a web site, then phone interview. To recruiter’s question on salary expectation I replied 25$ per hour, based on my experience in this industry. Recruiter told that they pay flat 22$ for this position. I agreed to that. A week after I got another phone interview with senior recruiter, we have not discussed the pay at all. Next day recruiter called me said there is a last step which is a face to face interview with manager. I successfully went through interview with manager, but we have not discussed pay with the him. I assumed flat 22$ means the same flat 22$. Next day got another call from different recruiter congratulating me and offering me 20$ per hour flat pay. I told that I was informed on initial interview that it was flat 22$. Recruiter immediately disagreed with me and said that’s the maximum that they can give me. No any reference or reason or apology explaining me why I was offered 22$ at the beginning. I felt like somebody is making fool of me. I contacted HR direct & advisor opened a case stating that they will "investigate the issue". Next day I got an email from that advisor stating that I have to contact back recruiter and nothing can be done at this point. So even reporting to HR will not do anything. I wish I recorded the conversation when they offered me flat 22$. I honestly did not expect this from company that promotes integrity and compassion. I did not see it. So if you are applying for a job, please be aware this is how pay questions are handled.

The schedules changed often and at the last minute. 
   Most employees were told the job was permanant and more then half of them were let go after AEP. The other half which were the top agents were put on "steady sate" and we were informed that less then 2 months in, we would all be let go within 8 days. We were given an opportunity to stay... For $3 less and no flexiblity on the schedule. Pretty much everyone promoted to coach/ supervisor or even upper management seemed to be the ones who lacked all common sense and were extremely lazy. I have NEVER worked for a place who could dish out so many lies and truly disrespect their employees in so many ways verbally, financially and mentally. Bonus, HAHA, I don't know one person that made the bonus, if you even get 1 bad review from a customer, you bonus for the month is gone, and the reviews are done over the phone and a lot of times (if they speak to more than one Vonage Rep) they don't realize who they are reviewing and review the wrong person, so you have NO control over you bonus. My training class and the 3 classes after me (that I was there for) HR messed up on our pay. Missed hours in our pay checks, after training is over, you get paid more, that didn't happen. Took a while for them to recompensate us, one person was actually put into the system for $1.00/hr instead of $11. Was supposed to get paid a $5 per phone line we opened, never saw one check and no way to check where you stand.

review_title: Join this company at your own risk
pros:
Good place to gain initial experience if you do not have any prior managed care experience

Great place to learn what NOT to do and how a managed care organization should NOT be run. This can be as important as learning what you should properly do to run a company correctly. I'm not trying to be funny here. I'm quite serious about this being a positive learning experience. As long as you aren't looking to retire from this place, the experience may be beneficial.

Career advancement exists if you are seeking to move up the corporate ladder. The company is growing very fast and there's a high employee turnover rate, so opportunities are constantly popping up, if that's your cup of tea.

They offer free beverages like tea, coffee, water
cons:
Long hours without additional compensation.  I mean 60+ hours per week and in some cases 14+ days of work without a break. If you value your personal time or have a family, you may want to think twice before taking a job here.

Horrible benefits. Most of the married workers, at least the pharmacists that I've spoken to, do not use the healthcare benefits offered by Optum, even though they all work for Optum. The benefits from their spouses' plans are much better. I'm single so I don't have another option, but I can say that the dental and vision benefits are horrible. You end up paying most of the bill out of your own pocket. I can only imagine what the medical benefits will be like if I need to use it to treat a major medical problem. 

I used to think this was at least a place with job security.  However, with some of the recent issues that have impacted the company, I'm not so sure about that any longer.

Senior management is far too removed from the actual work and should not be making any decisions that impact the operational, day to day work. Unfortunately, they often do make these decisions and it causes unnecessary additional work or introduces new inefficiencies.

Management is continually making decisions to cover their own butts and ensure their own job security, even at the expense of the employees' work-life balance, employee morale, and the overall company. They should be leading the company and looking for ways to make improvements. Instead they often spend their time and energy trying to shift blame on another department and take the CEO's scrutiny away from themselves.

The company is technologically challenged.  Access, Excel, and an outdated claims system are considered acceptable platforms by senior management, when the rest of the industry is using far more sophisticated tools.  Our senior managers refuse to invest in new applications and are too short sighted to see that the long term consequences will be the downfall of the company.

review_title: Moving in the wrong direction. Consulting candidates take note.
pros:
Embraces virtual work environment.
Handful of knowledgeable and respectable people who are  “in the trenches”.
Interesting project work.
Generous paid time off/vacation.
Benefits and salary aren’t anything great, but you could do worse elsewhere.
cons:
I can only speak for the consulting area:
Recent mass layoffs in Q4-2012 and continued uncertainty about further layoffs. 
- Layoffs did not target underperformers. Instead, it targeted people in certain locations who were managing others (in order to flatten the org). If a consulting firm’s main asset is its people, why would you ever lay off (and then subsequently hire back some) good people who are meeting or exceeding goals? To reward executives for smoke-and-mirror SG&A cost reductions??
- Morale is at its lowest…and getting lower with each passing day.

Recent changes in senior leadership have rotated in people who can’t properly lead and executive leadership does not understand the core consulting business.
- Laid off resources with strong client relationships and/or were exceeding targets. It appears that HR has more control over the business than the senior leadership team.
- Prior leaders knew how to communicate what a “bench” is and how investing in people leads to bigger and better things for the team
- Lip service to training. Why train someone when you can get 100+% utilization from them?
- Some wonder whether Optum even wants to have a consulting arm in the long-term (let alone a high-performing one).
- Very little cohesiveness and culture. You’re there to do your job and that’s it.

Reorganizations have occurred at least 1x/year. Some people have had 3 managers in the same year.

UHG, by and large, is a “cheap” company but Optum takes it to the extreme.  Don’t expect any fun networking events, training or even company social events. Don’t expect top-notch software or hardware.

Optum is preparing to spin-off from UnitedHealthcare and is doing anything and everything to position the company in an optimal financial light for Wall Street. They’ve cut the fat, cut into the muscle and have hit the bone in several areas.

The IT policies and tools they provide are sub-par and at times, are a hindrance to getting the job done.  Bureaucratic and arcane hoops to jump through are around every corner.

Expect to travel frequently, and most likely to the west coast or midwest…not the east coast.

review_title: Lies, Poverty Wages - It's the Connextions Way!
pros: A lot of nice, professional people work for Connextions, just not in management.
cons:
They will lie about your pay, about career opportunities and about job security to get you to do your job. There are no raises. When they are getting ready to lay people off, they start telling you there will be no layoffs. They will not promote you. They will not pay promised bonuses, or performance pay unless you cheat the system. Regardless of your education or credentials they will not listen or promote within because they believe agents are not intelligent. Training materials are poorly written, often do not make any sense are are never updated to reflect current practices. Coaches will ignore complaints and allow QA to do copy and paste reviews to get them done quickly rather than accurately. Agents are not allowed to speak to Human Capital (they don't have a human resources department) because we bother them. Agents are not allowed to dispute anything. Agents given minimal information that can be found by customers already and nothing more than that. Agents are not given access to required systems then punished for not having access. Expect to have your benefits disappear and reappear at whim. Benefits are minimal and you can't use your health coverage on they pay they give. The only raise in two years was because one of the site managers accidentally told agents they would be paid a higher rate when he was only supposed to tell bilingual agents.
Finally suggestions for improvement are promptly ignored and follow ups result in the agent being told they are not qualified to make that suggestion.

review_title: Low pay, ridiculous amounts of overtime, and no opportunities for advancement or salary increases!!!
pros: There are no pros for this position or company.
cons:
Everything.  This was she worst job I have ever had, and to quantify that my first job was Fry Cook at Dairy Queen.  To begin with, I have a Master's degree and the majority of my coworkers had GED or HS diploma education yet they made 3 to 4 dollars more per hour than me.  This company is all about nepotism, my manager had her sister hired into a supervisory role and they both worked in the same department.  There are several cases of that going on here.  I was hired and informed the rate of pay no negotiation and people who started with me with less education and experience made on average 5 to 6 thousand dollars more annually.  Explain that.

As a claims examiner, you will spend your day monitored down to a fraction of a second.  You are only allowed to take bathroom breaks during your 15 minute breaks or on lunch...if you have to go at another time prepared to be forced to work off the clock after your shift.  You will be called out for stealing from the company if the need to urinate arises and it is not your scheduled time to be away from your desk.  I suggest purchasing Depends if you value your job.

They do not give raises because they set the bar so high it is impossible to make your goals.  It is akin to working in a prison as a prisoner.  You will be required to work seven days a week just to hit your overtime hours and you will be rewarded with nothing.  

If you like working 10-15 hours overtime per week and being chained to computer while wearing an adult diaper then this is the place for you.

review_title: They talk a good game, but in the end they don't deliver on their empty words.
pros: Some of the products they offer are quite interesting.  Employees can purchase stock at a 15% discount which helps to save for things like Christmas, vacations, etc.  There are some good opportunities, but many are a risk because positions and teams are always changing so that good promotion may get you marked redundant. (unnecessary)  Some managers, and leaders are very good and know the job they supervise so they can actually guide their employee.  (Unfortunately, this is many times the exception, not the rule)  Good time off policy (1 bank of time to include sick and vacation)  but if you decide to leave you will lose it.   For many it's difficult to get time off that they have in their bank.
cons:
Company is constantly reorganizing, and with that offices are closed and job functions disappear.  A number of managers are prejudicial and you can see it when they take over a office or team.  Suddenly the makeup of the team changes quickly (over a year or so) from ethnicity, sexual orientation, or religion.  No one looks at demographics to question it, a blind eye is turned.   HR is not done by UHG, but is also outsourced.  But even the outsource company doesn't give consistent answers and the company is notorious about not giving the full policy to employees (doesn't matter if it is Dental, Vision, Medical, or HR they quote the pretty picture and then when an exception comes up they say "it's in our policy....."  Not that the employee can see it.  

As for regulations UHG makes the grand gesture in their written policies, but then doesn't support them with staff or hours to comply.  So they are never done or only done minimally. At least until a regulator comes then its time to run around and look like they've been doing it all along.  

Most entry level leaders are driven to keep employees who walk in the door and don't want to be there.  "We paid so much to recruit them."  So everyone else suffers them not doing their job or not doing it right.  Finally, mgmt will take action, maybe some "coaching" which is a fancy way of referring to a discussion that you aren't meeting X or Y.    Most projects never get done properly because upper mgmt always wants everything yesterday, most things aren't planned with enough lead time to execute them well, or if they are the time is moved up.   Example, they have been saying they are migrating soon to a new desktop OS.... at least 3 years but true to form in 2009 reorganization resulted in the ball getting dropped for over a year.  Wish they did real supply chain mgmt, it would have reduced a lot of headaches.  Since no system does everything it was intended to do everything has a work around.  Service reps have to access 9 to 14 systems to service many calls.   If you decide to work for UHG be aware of their rep for reorganization and keep copies (paper) of everything if you have a problem boss since if it's in their system it's their property.  Also, employees are their last concern For a health organization benefits are really somewhat sad.

pros:
Health insurance premiums can be low if you jump through all the hoops to qualify for "gold status" which left me with monthly premiums of about $10. Otherwise it's at least $100 for one individual on a low-premium plan. 

I did really enjoy the amount of time off I could get. Even if I had used up my PTO, my supervisors would allow me to take off as many Unpaid days as I wanted. So when things came up, I didn't stress. Other colleagues in the same office contended that their supers wouldn't allow them to take Unpaid time, so don't count on it.
cons:
I can only speak as someone in the Claims Department, and say that if you go to a job fair and get put in a Claims Dept position, you will be underpaid and underemployed for as long as it takes you to leave the company. Without revealing specific company practices and policies, I would only say, don't do Claims. If you have any integrity or self-respect, you don't belong processing Claims. The policies make it impossible to succeed consistently and maintain your integrity. It's very sad, and I am a pleasant, energetic person. If you're in Claims, you're bottom sludge. Less than a cog in the wheel. After more than 4 years with the company, I only received less than a 30 cent raise One time I got a $200 bonus for pumping out so many claims "error free" for three months. Trouble is, when less than .05% of the work you do is being audited, how is that error free? 

Irritating corporate jargon, daily emails emphasizing the company's demand for Honesty, Integrity, Compassion, and yet if you work in Claims they will refuse to interview you for a position that is more appropriate for your degree and skills. They will say, even if they consider you, that it's just "company policy" that they can't offer you more than 10% to do the new job. Even if your peers would be earning double your salary.

The only way to do well in this company is to jump in and out. I've heard encouraging things about the company from friends and colleagues who had managed to get out of Claims (Dante's Inferno), and they say it is a universe of difference once outside that realm. I applied to more than 80 internal job postings, got three interviews and one job offer to move to San Antonio and teach others how to do my job for 14 dollars an hour, which I rejected. I never made it outside of claims. But if you don't need money, and like sitting at a computer and taking a year of constant training to learn your job for only $11/hr, certainly Go Claims.

After working in Claims for UHC, I am afraid that all mega corps are engaging in the same practices of profits over accuracy, and making metrics so that only those who cut corners can meet them, and hope with a fair amount of confidence that no errors are caught in the process. In my experience, most months I had only 12 or 18 claims audited, and I had paid or denied 3 thousand. Scary practices.

pros: The best part of the job is that you work from home at your own pace and do not have to deal with your senior medical director often. Compensation is fair for the mindless reviews required and absence of thought provoking work usually required at other similar jobs at other large companies. You can completely 'zone out' and not concern yourself with the political and backstabbing that goes on in the company.
cons:
The clinical coverage management is totally malignant. They send you to all of this culture workshop stuff that management throws out of the window and refuses to apply. 

The CCR management is reminiscent of high school with cliques. Certain people get preferential treatment, promotions, and inadequacies overlooked if they belong to this clique. Management is also easily threatened by smarter or more innovative thinkers and will go out of their way to discourage and discredit them. Some senior medical directors even lie for their own advancements. The whole department needs reorganization. Instead of revamping the department, they promoted the two most malignant and dishonest senior medical directors to VPs. This has added a whole other layer of mismanagement. No one trusts their leadership and many medical directors stay on because it is work from home with fair compensation and you can disengage from leadership. If you want to advance from a medical director to management, this is not the place for you. There are plenty of places like Aetna, Cigna, Humana, and Anthem in which you will have better luck for career advancement. If you have a young family and being available to them is a priority and you don't care for such politics and don't mind not thinking much, United will work out great for you. Please heed this warning though: keep your head down, ignore any process flaw, don't try to improve anything, and never act smarter or show than you could possibly know more than your boss! Good luck if you get hired.

job_title: Associate Pharmacy Technician in Overland Park, KS
pros: Free coffee, tea, hot chocolate, and covered parking. Cafeteria on site.
cons:
The list is so long, have no idea where to even start. 
Horrible middle management (i.e., leads, supervisors)
Blatant favoritism.
Mandatory overtime consisting of as much as 18-20 hours a week, with little or no advance notice. When OT is voluntary and you do not volunteer it is held against you by supervisors and they make no bones about it. Will say if you don't volunteer it will be reflected in what schedule you get put on and in your annual review.
Told by supervisors to give 4's or higher on Vital Signs review or don't answer the question at all, no 3's or lower are to be given.
Almost impossible to use any PTO as weeks are blacked out the week before and the week, after, all holidays.
All new hires are contractors. Employees that have been there for years do not get any seniority over them in regards to time off or schedules choices.
The pharmacists who should be held in high regard are treated like crap, some technicians, leads and supervisors treat them terribly. Some supervisors think the pharmacists should take orders from them, not the other way around. Who went to school for 6 or more years getting a PharmD degree?
If you are not one of the favorites, start looking for a real job, as they will force you out.
Place is filthy dirty, only clean when VIP's are coming or there is a tour. 
Impossible to advance. 
No pay raises or so minimal it's insulting 10 -15 cents.
Started a program called BRAVO where one could nominate others for going above and beyond, some just give them back and forth to each other for no reason. Became so bad they almost stopped the program. Yet, supervisors who approve them are not held accountable. When you get enough points to purchase a large screen TV, something is terribly wrong.

job_title: Provider Service Representative in Maryland Heights, MO
pros: The hours are good. It’s a day job with weekends off.
cons:
*Feels like a sweatshop with calls back to back most of the day. Feel overworked for the pay taking calls for claims, benefits AND authorizations for providers. Speaking with others friends in my field that work for different companies, they’re getting paid more by just doing authorizations. Once the call ends with a provider, you are getting another calls in another seven seconds (this is most of the day). 

*Management doesn’t accommodate for employees but expect you to do everything perfect on each call. Bonuses are based on surveys from providers so it can be subjective.

*Ever since UHC started construction on our building, it seems like we’ve been overworked, with no new training classes to expand our department and relieve the back to back calls. (I’m not sure but seems like the budget shifted into the construction or other things instead of improving work-life balance for employees hmmm...). 

*In training it was always explained that you can move up within the company after a year, but I do not know anyone in my department that actually moved up after a year. I actually don’t see a lot movement at all in my department even though it is an entry level job. Most of the time I notice employees are being ‘moved up’ to mini projects in the same department with no pay increase. When explained to supervisor on moving lateral with the company, they do very little to help with that process. It feels as if you’re applying as an external candidate. Don’t hear anyone even getting interviews. 

*Your scheduled vacation hours and sick hours are combined so hopefully you don’t get sick before a vacation...they will use your PTO hours for those sick days. The days you actually scheduled off, will have the risk of being canceled (and of course you will get a occurrence against your attendance. Seven of these and you are out the door.)

review_title: United Health Needs To Do Better
pros: I have a better understanding of Health Insurance Industry; Majority of the people are nice to work with.
cons:
The desks,seats, keyboards, monitors and restrooms are not very clean. No raises, low pay for all the work they expect of you. During the crisis with the economy, UHC started firing employees for trivial infractions  such as coughing on the phone and for grammar related errors like saying "seen" when maybe you should say the word "saw". They switched representatives jobs and didn't give the training for the job they were expecting them to do. When those employee's started making mistakes, they were written up and up to terminated (it didn't matter that they hadn't received the proper training for the job they were doing).  No employee is treated the same across the board:  whether you can do an awesome job doesn't matter--it only matters if you get a supervisor or manager that likes you and will vouch for you. The right hand doesn't know what the left hand is doing..half the employees are doing their job based on old information while the other half have the updated information. Management gives conflicting information and the supervisors don't stand by anything they tell you even if they gave it to you in writing.  

For an insurance company, they have some of the worse health plans. We voiced our opinions about the desire for better health plans and to show how little they listen, our health plans got worse: we have very high deductibles and are being forced to use HSA's where the funds must build up in the account. Until then, we are responsible for ALL medical services. Of course we will be able to use fsa's but only for vision and dental...we can't even use it for prescriptions (it's limited because we will have a HSA). 

Getting time off is hard to do because out of over 200 people, if 3 are already off, they can't possibly spare a 4th person to be off. I feel the calls are not evenly distributed among representatives when you have two different people taking the same types of calls and one person is getting back to back calls while the other is getting a call every 5-10 minutes. 

Their systems (computers & phones) are HORRIBLE. And that UES survey!!!!!  they don't even know how it truly works yet they allow the survey results to be used in our metrics which ultimately affect our bonuses, the opportunity to get a decent schedule & work from home. The UHC phone system is notorious for dropping calls....but with UES, the call disconnects from the representative & transfers the caller to the survey where the caller leaves a horrible rating for the representative even though that representative never actually got a chance to handle the call. 2 or more of the survey questions asked conflict with how we are told to do our jobs: it basically asks if we explained benefits in a way that they can understand it...however, we are told by management NEVER interpret the benefits..read benefits just as they are in the system (which is usually surrounded with a bunch of legal jargon that even us representatives don't understand). its a no win situation because if we go out on a limb and try to explain the benefit, we lose our bonus, get a bad schedule on the next shift bid, and if  you are a work at home rep, you have to go into the office for 90days. if we do as told and read exactly what's in the system without interpreting the benefit for the caller, we get a bad survey...which results in loss of bonus,a bad schedule, and if  you are a work at home rep, into the office you go for 90days.  Originally we were told bad surveys would be reviewed by the individual supervisor or manager to determine if they are valid or actually belonged to that individual but that changed. Now, if you are unlucky enough to get a caller who likes you but is unsatisfied with UHC as a company...AND they clearly say in the survey message, "susie-q is a great representative but uhc is a horrible company and needs to do better",   you are out of luck and stuck with that bad survey.

review_title: Research Before Working At UHC Community & State Division
pros: The pay is relatively decent.
cons:
By far the worst company I've ever worked for and I've been around awhile.  There are certain "pockets" of the company that are good (I've heard Optum is good), but those pockets are limited.  However,  the "Community & State" branch is horrible.

-  First, check out the reviews of "Americhoice" too.  They went through a name change in 2010.  There are many more accurate reviews there specifically about this branch of United.
-  Unless you have a Minnesota address, those in Minnetonka won't take you seriously.  Upward mobility is limited because It's hard to stroke the right egos if you're not on Data Park Drive.
-  Sr. Leadership makes ignorant decisions in their ivory tower and ignore the expertise everywhere else in the organization.
-  They walk a very very thin line when it comes to ethics and integrity (in my opinion).
-  I wish an undercover reporter could work there for a few years.  The world could see how the states' Medicaid dollars are spent on dysfunctional, political leadership who can't get out of their own way.  
-  Sr. Leaders are RUTHLESS.  Don't just take my word for it - look at "Americhoice" on Glassdoor too.  They'll fire good, talented, proven people all the time - you can get an "Exceeds Expectations" on your review on Monday and be fired by Friday.
-  Extreme cronie'ism.  If you are unlucky enough to get a new leader, expect that you may be fired so they can bring in their friends and their own people.  That seems to be an accepted practice that I saw routinely.
-  Politics, not performance, will be the only way you will survive and thrive.

This is not feedback from an average "disgruntled" employee.  I've held leadership positions at many companies and there is nothing like UHG when it comes to how this organization is run.  I wasn't on the outside making assumptions - I was in the thick of it with these Senior Leaders.  I actually left this job and chose unemployment in a bad economy because it was so horrible.  Even if you're desperate for a job, you need to think twice about signing on with Community and State.

pros: They pay was great. That's about it.
cons:
I don't know where to even start. I was hired in with a supervisor that worked on the other side of the state that had absolutely no clue on what our department performed. Even worse, those that did work in the department were never trained and hadn't a clue how to show me how to do the job. A few months in, I was trained to use a certain computer system and was moved to a different team. We did have a bit of training from someone on the team that had been there for years. However, it had been some time since she had performed our job and constantly gave out wrong information in which we were audited on. Errors were a big no no and you were kindly informed with a big red ! that you've done something wrong. On top of having a quality and production standard that was nearly possible to accomplish, everyone on the team save for a few of us worked from home. Trust me when I say, sitting in an office while you listen to your co-workers birds in the background can make you twinge a little with envy. There's a little chance you'll get a day off. Most days are taken up before you can consider taking them off. You also cannot call in sick more than three times, regardless if you're on your death bed.  Deal with being overwhelmed and stressed with the unlimited/constantly changing SOPs that make it even harder to perform your job to what is expected of you, you also have kiss up to get ahead. If not, be prepared to have your supervisor demean you in whatever snide way they can without being to blatant about it. Your supervisor depending on your department, will not have your back. Fight your own battles, even if you're right, even if the person you're up against is in so many words calling you an idiot. You're on your own. If that wasn't bad enough (yes there's more) eventually we were told constantly that we were going to be laid off but weren't given dates or any information other than to wait and see. Eventually a few of us did get laid off and was told to quit doing what we were doing and leave during the middle of the work day. It certainly made me feel like I was a valued employee to have been as dedicated as I was while all the folks that couldn't "train me" stand around chatting all day only to be laid off. They're still employed at UHG which makes me wonder if I brown nosed enough and did everything but my job that I'd still have one there.

If only I could've given this company 0 stars.

pros: Truly cares about their members and making sure they hire people to fill those seats.
cons: For this to be a billion dollar company I expected so much more. The interview process itself was a lengthy process. The hiring managers were quick to get me to fill out the assessment and conduct the phone interview however afterwards it took months to hear back about when the training would start. I didn’t receive the information regarding start date and location until the weekend of. While in training we trained in an open room right next to another set of training classes so we had to keep our voices down and do a lot of our learning through websites with our headsets on. The training itself was an overview not an actual in depth training. Everyday we came in and learned a new system never reviewing the previous materials.  With the facility being new to the Dublin area all of our management was brought in from outside companies or from other UHC sites so no one seemed to know what they were doing or how this site was going to run. The supervisor still doesn’t know what he’s doing in his role so he provided no help when we were on the floor facing issues. His answers was always I don’t know never once did he point us in the direction of where to get answers. The attendance policy was never fully disclosed until a number of agents were on corrective actions because again it was the blind leading the blind. We weren’t fully equipped to help the members to the best of our abilities. The assistance/mentors they brought it barely answered questions and had attitudes when being asked to help. There were very few team meetings, feedback seemed to fall on deaf ears, & there was absolutely no coaching at all before we were considered experienced agents. All in all if I had never heard of United healthcare I would’ve thought this was a start up company just finding its way. As a result a lot of us from my training class have quit with just a few months experience under our belts. To add there’s no cafeteria in the building. The food they do have to offer is old and kept in a lil fridge and far more expensive than any fast food or gas station. They don’t give out any company merchandise for you to show you work for their company. There’s no team bonding. Upper management never introduces themselves they just walk around as if you’re suppose to know who they are. Management favors certain agents over others and it shows. This is a company that doesn’t care about their employees at all. They don’t listen to the feedback given, they give you a million and one responsibilities on top of you taking emotionally distressing calls, they lack organization and consistency, and they do not fully disclose the job details to you at the time of hire. There is NO work life balance. You are to be at your desk at the start of your shift no grace period, attendance remarks don’t fall off for an entire year, you are REQUIRED to do mandatory overtime regardless of if you have children, school, outside commitments or not.

review_title: Look elsewhere if you are a seasoned IT professional and want to do more than push papers.
job_title: IT Project Manager in Minneapolis, MN
pros: It's a good company for women returning to work and there are opportunities to move within the company.  Some offices have cafeterias and fitness centers as well as health coaches.  Some can telecommute.  The hours are usually in the 45-50 hour range.
cons: Their mission statement is "Helping people live healthier lives." but you will find little to support that.  At UHG, most of the money here is shoveled to the CEO which is widely publicized and public information.  Bonuses are available but usually not paid out, there can be a lot of red tape to get claims paid, and little perks are slowly stripped away (flavored teas, etc.) yet the CEO still cashes in.  You will find substandard benefits with high deductible plans which are are a challenge for younger employees seeking to start a family, especially when you have a $6,000 deductible not to mention out-of-pocket expenses paid at 80% if you are lucky.  As a result, there is a lot of frustration within the ranks but rather than bonding together, you will find that many employees are hostile and very difficult to work with.  On the management side, what's good for the goose is not necessarily good for the gander.  For example, many employees are tied to a hub location so if you leave that location, you are a target to be forced to resign but this does not apply to directors and vice presidents.  In terms of IT, the group lacks sophistication at the executive level so they latch onto current industry trends such as PMP and Agile rather than evaluating what works for their business model and developing a methodology that suits their needs.  Some of this is because they want to take the Optum services to the commercial market and believe that PMI credentials and specific methodologies will provide sales opportunities but internally, their processes are so tied up in red tape and copious documents, which naturally take time away from effective and productive activities, that execution is and will be a challenge.  If you are a domestic employee, your job will always be at risk because they offshore a large amount of their work and when regulations prevent offshoring, they bring people in on H-1B visas rather than seeking local talent.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Jeffersonville, IN
pros: None at all.  Don't waste your time. Flip burgers if you have to, but stay away from these people!
cons:
Lies from day one!  They lie about the salary, They lie about the training,  The "benefit s" are a joke.   The deductible for the health insurance is more than 3 months of your take home pay.

The training is ridiculous, half of the time the computers didn't work or we couldn't get access to applications we needed to be trained on.

They were so unprofessional, one of the trainers spent 1.5 hours of our precious training time talking about her "baby daddy" problems!

We were assured 8 weeks of training, we barely got 6.  We were thrown to the wolves and, of course, the coaches were of no help!

The computers are just updated to Windows 7 Enterprise in 2015...lol. Previously, they were still running Windows XP...in 2014!!!

The "coaches" are a huge joke.  They spend all their time either in meetings or hanging out in the lounge.  

When you ask them a question or have a a call that needs to involve a supervisor, they'll ask you a million questions before taking the call and/or take 10 minutes before taking the call while the agent has to keep telling the angry caller, " my supervisor will be right with you."

Major changes in members' policy are never told to the agents until there are hundreds of calls where you have no idea what the caller is referring to.

When they do tell you anything, then send it in an email, then don't give you enough time to read it!!!

Then you have the quality people, they sit and listen to you calls and nitpick every little thing you do, so you can't make PFP bonus.

Adherence is a joke!  The software changes your lunch and breaks, so, again, you'll miss your adherence goal and they'll withhold PFP.

The PFP only comes out to about $175 a month, which they try every which way to jerk the agents out of getting any way they can!

They make their money based on how many calls get answered.  They don't care if agents know what they're talking about or not.  Just as long as the calls get answered.. Then they punish agents for not knowing what they weren't taught!

As for advancement, don't even at
attempt it if you don't have the right "friends!"

*some friendly cliques, if you land on the right team
*building facilities could be worse (could be better!)
*fortune 15
*work from home & remote work possibilites
cons:
*leadership vision/strategy is awful, ego-maniacal and unsustainable
*managerial/directorial strategy is to cater to those above, rather than work with those below
*constant "state of emergency" work environment, negating the work/life balance they pretend to promote
*really have to be able to tune out that your paycheck comes from extorting money from consumers
*as an employee, you are viewed as a consumer. Ironically, work somewhere else to get better, UHC-administered health plan options.
*Big egos with poor working styles
*can't work here if you're bothered by seeing obvious holes in projects or plans - I've seen many ppl come and go because they actually want to do good work. That's not the name of the game here; it's about catering to leaders
*the coworkers who do well are more likely to be canned without notice than the awful leadership when things go awry (which they quite often do)
*lots of Target people hired after layoffs there, but for even higher level positions here; it has had a noticeably negative effect on the workflow here as they bring in methods that failed their former employer in the long run
