*Health offerings, classes, culture ->all next to non-existent, though they will keep talking about what pittance that does exist as the bee's knees. Employee well-being is NOT a priority of theirs ("We can't just give them things, because then they will want more and more" - direct quote from the CEO). 
*talent mobility is much less of a phenomenon here than they will sell it to you...very rarely do you see anyone promoted - no special treatment for already working there; you're on equal footing with outside talent and talent across the company. 
*bonuses/raises/etc. from reviews: completely up in the air, at the whim of how much the C-levels think they want to spend on EE's. easy to be fooled it's based on merit.

review_title: Excellent PTO, everything else is subppar
pros: PTO is excellent, co-workers are awesome
cons:
Promotions are not well thought out, they are given to unqualified people who either are in the buddy system or promoted to a position of trust when no action would merit trust for these individuals.  The mess from these promotions are left to the client facing people to clean up time and time again.  

Change is the standard modus operandi at Ingenix.  If you don't like how it is today, wait 6 months and it will change again.  This doesn't allow for change to work, on the other hand, it's only 6 months for a bad decision to be replaced by another bad decision.

Senior leaderships inability to understand their employees is what make them appear unable to lead this company where it should have gone several years ago.  Ingenix is the technology arm of the UHG empire yet the technology employed at Ingenix is years old and in most cases desupported by the vendor.  This issue could be easily resolved with competent technology leadership rather than advancing someone who has no leadership or technology experience.

Finally, benefits are horrible, especially health benefits.  For a company that makes billions upon billions of dollars in profit you would think as an employee our rates could be better than let's say my neighbor who gets the same coverage for a better prices from his company.

review_title: Stay away if you have a desire for a work/life balance.
pros:
UHG IT has much cutting edge technology that you will not find in smaller organizations.  
The health care benefits are not great but if you’re in good health the premiums are relatively competitive.  If you have a chronic health condition expect a lot of out of pocket costs.
cons: UGH IT is a chaotic environment that puts too much emphasis on meeting dates rather than delivering quality and system stability.  The first rule there is CYA, second rule is don’t forget the first rule.  It is a silo-centric organization that lacks goal congruency.  Lower management has no authority to manage their teams; they are pawns to directors who want to report on all their “achievements”.  Directors have no issue breaking the backs of the people in their organizations time and again.  Overly aggressive dates are set by leaders who don’t understand (or just don’t care about) the process flow of the organization.  To achieve the most basic IT build requires countless meetings and filling out more forms than the IRS has before you can begin the actual work.  By then you’re up against your timeline so you have to work like mad to meet it or deliver something to smoke and mirror Sr. leaders. It’s a relentless cycle where something is always in a “critical” phase that requires you to work late and weekends…  While they do pay performance bonuses, they are best described as blood money.  Talented people leave because there is no regard for a work/life balance.  If the US economy ever gets back on track, this company will be screwed by an exodus of talented people

review_title: Quit after getting trained. Use the time to find a better job.
pros: There was, maybe, two or three attractive women working there out of hundreds.
cons:
An insurance company that does not provide health benefits to the majority of their employees. If you suck up to management, the fat women that run your section may deem you worthy of receiving minimum health coverage. However you must be first kiss up and pull some Machiavellian maneuvering.
They pay you next to nothing and then increase your workload over time, but not your wage. You are making just enough to eek by but not enough to be able to afford to take a day off to look for better work. 
The Supervisors, at least the one I have in mind, will play childish little games with malicious intent that effect your paycheck while barely doing anything herself, work wise.
When you are forced to go over her head, her immediate supervisor is a weak, ineffectual little man who gets nervous and tells you to call the HR hotline, sparing himself the responsibility of actually stepping up and making decisions.
Inclement weather? Do not go in if you are not listed as 'full time' employee, meaning they have grudgingly given you permanent status and, even more loathsome to them, benefits. They will close early and you will only be paid for the time you were there, not the full day.
Supervisors and the other club members get full dull day pay, but not you, even if they say you will and even though you risked just as much to get there. Wrecked on your way home? Tough luck. Only partial pay for that day.
As I said when I titled this review, get paid for training and then quit. Skip a couple of training days to interview at a better job.
By that I mean, a company run by fair professionals, lazy overweight women ho earned their position through a 'diversity' effort, rather than actual performance.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: pay can get to a point of being good if you're willing to stick things out long enough to make decent money
cons: very very stressful I was able to learn of a preexisting heart condition thanks to the extreme levels of stress this job puts on you. Prepare to get yelled at for no reason by roughly 8/10 members that call. prepare to be micromanaged on every little stat that is given to you. Your job is always on the line. If you miss a day that's a point. If you're sick that's a point. If you're in the hospital that's a point. 7 points and you're out. Family issues, yea that's also a point.  Any illness that causes you to miss more than 3 days and they want you to file for short term disability knowing full well the claim will be denied. Also the Favorites game is strong in that office if you aren't on of the chosen few don't expect to have any downtime. If you voice your concern, prepare to get more calls than anyone else around  you. Your status in the call queue will be adjusted and you will be put as top priority in all queues, even the ones for calls you aren't trained on. The average person ends up taking roughly 35-45 calls a day. When you are being pushed as priority be ready to crank out at least 90+.  Then that brings me to the actual work we were trained to do. If your are promoted and told you will handle medicare and medicaid dual eligible calls for 3 states it makes it sound like a pretty simple task,but then they say oh wait you have to do basic medicaid calls for all of Texas. Then you have to handle dual eligible calls for 13 other states starting today when you've had no training on the differences in the plans those states offer. Finally all advancement within the company comes down to your manager. If you want to move to a new campaign, move to a new dept. it's all up to your manager, if they have even the slightest issue with you, then don't expect to move up in the company.

review_title: I would give a negative if I could.
job_title: Claims Processor in Eau Claire, WI
pros:
Not talking to customers. 
I could listen to my music/podcast.
cons:
Worked for almost a year until I had to go through medical issues. I tried to file for  STD but the HR rep on the phone said I did not qualify. I was never offered FMLA like my other 19 year old "Pregnant" coworker. UHC/UHG does not accept doctor's note or certification, so you have to be there even when you're dying and in the hospital bed. 
So much for being in the health care business.. yet you don't even care about your own employee's health.
I kept missing work because I had no idea why I kept going into the hospital. I was there for days before being discharged. After I returned, I was told I was fired. Only then, 2 days later after doing so biopsy and tests, I found out I had stage 1a Ovarian Cancer. I called the HR department again, to try to resolve my being fired and they said that I could have had filed for STD or FMLA. I was in complete shock. My first original call was to FILE for short term disability!! I had no idea what FMLA was... I was just a 21 year old who was going into the adult world and someone should have offered that to me when I was denied.  The HR person was rude and said, there was no note about me calling in to file for anything. Well then what the heck did I call in for? 
I consulted a lawyer but was told it was going to be a hard case since I had no recording or written proof. I was screwed. 
THANKS, UHC for screwing up my LIFE!

After being let go, I found out, I was the lowest paying employee compared to everyone in my training class. They looked down on me because I was a minority and female. While everyone was getting paid 12-14/ hour, I was only getting paid 11.25/hr. and I'm the one with experience. During the interview, they made it sound like I was getting paid the most. Shocker.
